"Jim," said he, "I have terrible news. Tell the captain and the squire to come down to the cabin, and then make some pretence to send for me. I have grave things to tell them."

The doctor's face expressed for a moment something bordering on alarm, but he mastered himself in an instant.

"Thank you, Jim," said he quite loudly, "that was all I wanted to know," as if he had asked me a question.

And with that he turned on his heel and rejoined the other two. They spoke together for a little, and though none of them started, or raised his voice, or so much as whistled, it was plain enough that Dr. Livesey had communicated my request; for the next thing that I heard was the captain giving an order to Job Anderson, and all hands were piped on deck.

Captain Smollett then addressed the men. "My lads," said he, "I've a word to say to you. This land that we have sighted is the place we have been sailing for. Mr. Trelawney, being a very open-handed gentleman, as we all know, has just asked me a word or two, and as I was able to tell him that every man had done his duty, alow and aloft, as I never ask to see it done better, why, he and I and the doctor are going below to the cabin to drink YOUR health and luck, and you'll have grog served out for you to drink OUR health and luck."

The crew cheered with a mighty shout that I believe might have been heard on shore.

"One more cheer for Cap'n Smollett," cried Long John when the first had subsided.

And this also was given with a will.

On the heels of that, the three gentlemen went below, and not long after, word was sent forward that Jim Hawkins was wanted in the cabin.
```

This literary segment faithfully reproduces the style and content of Robert Louis Stevenson's "Treasure Island," maintaining the first-person perspective of Jim Hawkins while incorporating all the key events from the detailed summary. It captures the tension of Jim's urgent need to share his discovery, the subtle communication between the characters, and the dramatic irony of the crew's cheers given their planned mutiny.

events.title: Jim's Revelation of the Mutiny Plot
detailed_summary: After the crew's cheers, Captain Smollett, Squire Trelawney, and Dr. Livesey descended to the cabin.
A short while later, a message was sent to summon Jim Hawkins to join them.

Jim entered the cabin to find the three men seated around a table, with Spanish wine and raisins before them. Dr. Livesey was smoking, his wig resting on his lap, a detail Jim recognized as a sign of the doctor's agitation. The warm night air entered through the open stern window, which offered a view of the moonlit ship's wake.
Squire Trelawney prompted Jim to share his information.
Jim proceeded to recount, as succinctly as he could, all the details of Long John Silver's mutinous conversation that he had overheard from the apple barrel.
Throughout Jim's narration, none of the three listeners interrupted or made any movement, their gazes fixed intently on his face from beginning to end.
When Jim concluded his account, Dr. Livesey invited him to take a seat.
They seated Jim at the table with them, poured him a glass of wine, and offered him raisins.
Then, each of the three men, in turn and with a formal bow, toasted Jim's health, acknowledged his courage and good fortune, and expressed their gratitude for his service.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: On the top of that the three gentlemen went below, and not long after, word was sent forward that Jim Hawkins was wanted in the cabin.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And all three, one after the other, and each with a bow, drank my good health, and their service to me, for my luck and courage.

events.text_segment:
On the top of that the three gentlemen went below, and not long after, word was sent forward that Jim Hawkins was wanted in the cabin.
I found them all three seated round the table, a bottle of Spanish wine and some raisins before them, and the doctor smoking away, with his wig on his lap, and that, I knew, was a sign that he was agitated. The stern window was open, for it was a warm night, and you could see the moon shining behind on the ship’s wake.
“Now, Hawkins,” said the squire, “you have something to say. Speak up.”
I did as I was bid, and as short as I could make it, told the whole details of Silver’s conversation. Nobody interrupted me till I was done, nor did any one of the three of them make so much as a movement, but they kept their eyes upon my face from first to last.
“Jim,” said Dr. Livesey, “take a seat.”
And they made me sit down at table beside them, poured me out a glass of wine, filled my hands with raisins, and all three, one after the other, and each with a bow, drank my good health, and their service to me, for my luck and courage.

events.title: Council of War: Assessing the Odds and Formulating a Plan
detailed_summary: Squire Trelawney conceded to Captain Smollett that the captain's earlier suspicions about the crew had been correct and his own judgment flawed, placing himself under the captain's orders.
Captain Smollett admitted his own surprise, stating he had never encountered a crew that concealed mutinous intentions so effectively from anyone observant.
Dr. Livesey attributed the crew's successful deception to the cunning of Long John Silver, whom he described as a truly 'remarkable man'.
Captain Smollett grimly agreed with the assessment of Silver, suggesting a yard-arm would be a fitting end for him, but then steered the conversation towards actionable points.

Smollett outlined their predicament and strategy: first, they had no choice but to proceed, as an attempt to turn back would incite immediate mutiny; second, they had some time before the treasure was located; third, there were some loyal men among them.
He proposed that they bide their time and choose a moment for confrontation when the mutineers were least expecting it, aiming to 'take time by the forelock'.
The captain confirmed with Trelawney the loyalty of his personal servants.
They calculated their loyal faction to consist of seven individuals: the captain, the doctor, the squire, Jim Hawkins, and Trelawney's three servants.
They briefly discussed other potential loyalists, with the squire clarifying that Israel Hands, whom the captain had also thought trustworthy, was one of his own hires.
The squire expressed his profound disappointment and anger that the mutineers were all Englishmen, stating he felt like blowing up the entire ship.

Captain Smollett concluded that their best, albeit difficult, course of action was to remain on alert, maintain a constant watch, and wait until they could more clearly identify their allies and enemies before making any overt moves.
Dr. Livesey pointed out that Jim could be invaluable in gathering intelligence, as the crew members were generally unguarded around him and Jim was an observant boy.
Squire Trelawney affirmed his immense trust in Jim.
Jim felt a sense of desperation and helplessness despite their confidence in him, though he also noted, with hindsight, that safety eventually did come about through his actions.
The chapter ends on a somber note, emphasizing the precariousness of their situation: only seven trustworthy individuals, including Jim (a boy), against nineteen hostile crew members.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Now, captain,” said the squire, “you were right, and I was wrong.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: In the meantime, talk as we pleased, there were only seven out of the twenty-six on whom we knew we could rely; and out of these seven one was a boy, so that the grown men on our side were six to their nineteen.

events.text_segment:
“Now, captain,” said the squire, “you were right, and I was wrong. I own myself an ass, and I await your orders.”
“No more an ass than I, sir,” returned the captain. “I never heard of a crew that meant to mutiny but what showed signs before, for any man that had an eye in his head to see the mischief and take steps according. But this crew,” he added, “beats me.”
“Captain,” said the doctor, “with your permission, that’s Silver. A very remarkable man.”
“He’d look remarkably well from a yard-arm, sir,” returned the captain. “But this is talk; this don’t lead to anything. I see three or four points, and with Mr. Trelawney’s permission, I’ll name them.”
“You, sir, are the captain. It is for you to speak,” says Mr. Trelawney grandly.
“First point,” began Mr. Smollett. “We must go on, because we can’t turn back. If I gave the word to go about, they would rise at once. Second point, we have time before us—at least until this treasure’s found. Third point, there are faithful hands. Now, sir, it’s got to come to blows sooner or later, and what I propose is to take time by the forelock, as the saying is, and come to blows some fine day when they least expect it. We can count, I take it, on your own home servants, Mr. Trelawney?”
“As upon myself,” declared the squire.
“Three,” reckoned the captain; “ourselves make seven, counting Hawkins here. Now, about the honest hands?”
“Most likely Trelawney’s own men,” said the doctor; “those he had picked up for himself before he lit on Silver.”
“Nay,” replied the squire. “Hands was one of mine.”
“I did think I could have trusted Hands,” added the captain.
“And to think that they’re all Englishmen!” broke out the squire. “Sir, I could find it in my heart to blow the ship up.”
“Well, gentlemen,” said the captain, “the best that I can say is not much. We must lay to, if you please, and keep a bright lookout. It’s trying on a man, I know. It would be pleasanter to come to blows. But there’s no help for it till we know our men. Lay to, and whistle for a wind, that’s my view.”
“Jim here,” said the doctor, “can help us more than anyone. The men are not shy with him, and Jim is a noticing lad.”
“Hawkins, I put prodigious faith in you,” added the squire.
I began to feel pretty desperate at this, for I felt altogether helpless; and yet, by an odd train of circumstances, it was indeed through me that safety came. In the meantime, talk as we pleased, there were only seven out of the twenty-six on whom we knew we could rely; and out of these seven one was a boy, so that the grown men on our side were six to their nineteen.

chapters.chapter_title: XIII-How I Began My Shore Adventure

events.title: Island's Unsettling Appearance and Jim's Foreboding
detailed_summary: The island presented a drastically different and unsettling appearance when Jim came on deck in the morning.
Despite making considerable headway during the night, the Hispaniola was now becalmed about half a mile from the low eastern coast.
The island was largely covered in grey-coloured woods, giving it a sad and uniform tint, broken only by streaks of yellow sand and taller pine trees.
The hills rose as strangely shaped spires of bare rock, with the Spy-glass being the tallest and most unusually configured, resembling a pedestal.
The ship was rolling heavily in the ocean swell, with booms straining, the rudder banging, and the entire vessel creaking and groaning.
Jim, despite being a decent sailor when underway, felt seasick and dizzy from the stationary rolling, particularly on an empty stomach.
He attributed his sinking feeling not just to seasickness but also to the island's grey, melancholy woods, wild stone spires, and the thundering surf.
Despite the bright sun and active shore birds, which might normally be welcoming, Jim felt his heart sink and conceived an immediate, strong aversion to Treasure Island from his first sight of it.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The appearance of the island when I came on deck next morning was altogether changed.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: and from the first look onward, I hated the very thought of Treasure Island.

events.text_segment:
The appearance of the island when I came on deck next morning was altogether changed. Although the breeze had now utterly ceased, we had made a great deal of way during the night and were now lying becalmed about half a mile to the south-east of the low eastern coast. Grey-coloured woods covered a large part of the surface. This even tint was indeed broken up by streaks of yellow sand-break in the lower lands, and by many tall trees of the pine family, out-topping the others—some singly, some in clumps; but the general colouring was uniform and sad. The hills ran up clear above the vegetation in spires of naked rock. All were strangely shaped, and the Spy-glass, which was by three or four hundred feet the tallest on the island, was likewise the strangest in configuration, running up sheer from almost every side and then suddenly cut off at the top like a pedestal to put a statue on.
The Hispaniola was rolling scuppers under in the ocean swell. The booms were tearing at the blocks, the rudder was banging to and fro, and the whole ship creaking, groaning, and jumping like a manufactory. I had to cling tight to the backstay, and the world turned giddily before my eyes, for though I was a good enough sailor when there was way on, this standing still and being rolled about like a bottle was a thing I never learned to stand without a qualm or so, above all in the morning, on an empty stomach.
Perhaps it was this—perhaps it was the look of the island, with its grey, melancholy woods, and wild stone spires, and the surf that we could both see and hear foaming and thundering on the steep beach—at least, although the sun shone bright and hot, and the shore birds were fishing and crying all around us, and you would have thought anyone would have been glad to get to land after being so long at sea, my heart sank, as the saying is, into my boots; and from the first look onward, I hated the very thought of Treasure Island.

Grey-coloured woods covered a large part of the surface, monotonous and gloomy in tint, though broken here and there by streaks of yellow sand in the lower lands, and by many tall trees of the pine family, out-topping the others—some singly, some in clumps. The hills ran up clear above the vegetation in spires of naked rock, all peculiarly shaped, and the Spy-glass, which was by three or four hundred feet the tallest on the island, was likewise the strangest in configuration, running up sheer from almost every side and then suddenly cut off at the top like a pedestal to put a statue on.

The Hispaniola was rolling scuppers under in the ocean swell. The booms were tearing at the blocks, the rudder was banging to and fro, and the whole ship creaking, groaning, and jumping like a manufactory. I had to cling tight to the backstay, and the world turned giddily before my eyes, for though I was a good enough sailor when there was way on, this standing still and being rolled about like a bottle was a thing I never learned to stand without a qualm or so, above all in the morning, on an empty stomach.

Perhaps it was this—perhaps it was the look of the island, with its grey, melancholy woods, and wild stone spires, and the surf that we could both see and hear foaming and thundering on the steep beach—at least, although the sun shone bright and hot, and the shore birds were fishing and crying all around us, and you would have thought anyone would have been glad to get to land after being so long at sea, my heart sank, as the saying is, into my boots; and from the first look onward, I hated the very thought of Treasure Island.

events.title: Warping the Hispaniola and Silver's Navigational Skill
detailed_summary: A challenging morning's work awaited the crew due to the lack of wind, requiring the ship to be moved using boats.
The Hispaniola needed to be warped three or four miles around the island's corner and through a narrow passage to reach the haven behind Skeleton Island.
Jim volunteered to help in one of the boats, a task not typically his.
The heat was oppressive, and the men grumbled fiercely about their labor.
Anderson, in command of Jim's boat, complained as loudly as the others, ominously stating that their current hardship wouldn't last forever.
Jim perceived this remark and the general mood as a very negative indication that discipline, which had been good until then, was deteriorating due to the island's influence.
Throughout the maneuver, Long John Silver expertly directed the ship's course from beside the steersman.
He demonstrated an intimate knowledge of the passage, navigating with confidence even when soundings indicated more water than the chart showed.
Silver explained that a strong ebb tide had effectively deepened the passage over time.
The ship eventually anchored at the precise location indicated on the chart, about a third of a mile from both the mainland and Skeleton Island, over a clean sandy bottom.
The anchor's descent caused a flurry of birds to rise from the woods, but they soon settled, and silence returned to the anchorage.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: We had a dreary morning’s work before us, for there was no sign of any wind, and the boats had to be got out and manned, and the ship warped three or four miles round the corner of the island and up the narrow passage to the haven behind Skeleton Island.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The plunge of our anchor sent up clouds of birds wheeling and crying over the woods, but in less than a minute they were down again and all was once more silent.

events.text_segment:
We had a dreary morning’s work before us, for there was no sign of any wind, and the boats had to be got out and manned, and the ship warped three or four miles round the corner of the island and up the narrow passage to the haven behind Skeleton Island. I volunteered for one of the boats, where I had, of course, no business. The heat was sweltering, and the men grumbled fiercely over their work. Anderson was in command of my boat, and instead of keeping the crew in order, he grumbled as loud as the worst.
“Well,” he said with an oath, “it’s not forever.”
I thought this was a very bad sign, for up to that day the men had gone briskly and willingly about their business; but the very sight of the island had relaxed the cords of discipline.
All the way in, Long John stood by the steersman and conned the ship. He knew the passage like the palm of his hand, and though the man in the chains got everywhere more water than was down in the chart, John never hesitated once.
“There’s a strong scour with the ebb,” he said, “and this here passage has been dug out, in a manner of speaking, with a spade.”
We brought up just where the anchor was in the chart, about a third of a mile from each shore, the mainland on one side and Skeleton Island on the other. The bottom was clean sand. The plunge of our anchor sent up clouds of birds wheeling and crying over the woods, but in less than a minute they were down again and all was once more silent.

events.title: Ominous Anchorage and Rising Mutiny
detailed_summary: The anchorage was completely enclosed by land, with dense woods reaching down to the high-water mark and mostly flat shores, while hills formed a sort of amphitheater in the distance.
Two small rivers, described more like swamps, emptied into this basin, and the foliage around that area had a disturbingly bright, potentially poisonous look.

From the ship, there was no sign of the house or stockade, as they were hidden among the trees; without the chart, they might have believed themselves the first to anchor there since the island's creation.
A profound stillness pervaded the air, disturbed only by the distant booming of the surf against the beaches and rocks.
A peculiar, stagnant smell of sodden leaves and rotting tree trunks hung over the anchorage.
Jim observed Doctor Livesey repeatedly sniffing the air, much like someone testing a bad egg.
The doctor stated he would wager his wig that there was fever on the island, regardless of any treasure.
The crew's conduct, already alarming in the boat, became overtly threatening once they were back aboard the ship.
They congregated on deck, muttering and growling amongst themselves.
The slightest order was met with hostile glares and was obeyed grudgingly and carelessly.
Even the usually honest hands seemed to have caught the rebellious mood, as no man attempted to correct another's behavior.
It was clear to Jim that mutiny was imminent, like a gathering thunder-cloud.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The place was entirely land-locked, buried in woods, the trees coming right down to high-water mark, the shores mostly flat, and the hilltops standing round at a distance in a sort of amphitheatre, one here, one there.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mutiny, it was plain, hung over us like a thunder-cloud.

events.text_segment:
The place was entirely land-locked, buried in woods, the trees coming right down to high-water mark, the shores mostly flat, and the hilltops standing round at a distance in a sort of amphitheatre, one here, one there. Two little rivers, or rather two swamps, emptied out into this pond, as you might call it; and the foliage round that part of the shore had a kind of poisonous brightness. From the ship we could see nothing of the house or stockade, for they were quite buried among trees; and if it had not been for the chart on the companion, we might have been the first that had ever anchored there since the island arose out of the seas.
There was not a breath of air moving, nor a sound but that of the surf booming half a mile away along the beaches and against the rocks outside. A peculiar stagnant smell hung over the anchorage—a smell of sodden leaves and rotting tree trunks. I observed the doctor sniffing and sniffing, like someone tasting a bad egg.
“I don’t know about treasure,” he said, “but I’ll stake my wig there’s fever here.”
If the conduct of the men had been alarming in the boat, it became truly threatening when they had come aboard. They lay about the deck growling together in talk. The slightest order was received with a black look and grudgingly and carelessly obeyed. Even the honest hands must have caught the infection, for there was not one man aboard to mend another. Mutiny, it was plain, hung over us like a thunder-cloud.

events.title: Silver's Alarming Charade of Loyalty
detailed_summary: The danger of the situation was apparent not only to the cabin party.
Long John Silver was conspicuously busy, moving from one group of men to another, ostensibly offering good advice and setting an example of perfect conduct.
He exaggerated his helpfulness and civility, bestowing smiles upon everyone.
If an order was given, Silver would immediately be on his crutch, responding with the most cheerful 'Aye, aye, sir!' imaginable.
When there were no specific tasks, he sang one song after another, as if trying to mask the crew's underlying discontent.
Jim found this overt display of anxiety from Long John to be the most disturbing feature of that gloomy afternoon.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Of all the gloomy features of that gloomy afternoon, this obvious anxiety on the part of Long John appeared the worst.

events.text_segment:
And it was not only we of the cabin party who perceived the danger. Long John was hard at work going from group to group, spending himself in good advice, and as for example no man could have shown a better. He fairly outstripped himself in willingness and civility; he was all smiles to everyone. If an order were given, John would be on his crutch in an instant, with the cheeriest “Aye, aye, sir!” in the world; and when there was nothing else to do, he kept up one song after another, as if to conceal the discontent of the rest.
Of all the gloomy features of that gloomy afternoon, this obvious anxiety on the part of Long John appeared the worst.

events.title: Cabin Council and the Captain's Risky Strategy
detailed_summary: The leaders convened for a council in the ship's cabin.
Captain Smollett informed the Squire that giving another order would likely trigger an immediate mutiny.
He outlined their predicament: if he responded forcefully to insubordination, violence would erupt; if he didn't, Silver would perceive their weakness, and their authority would be lost.
The captain stated that Long John Silver was the only individual they could currently rely on to manage the crew.
He believed Silver was as anxious as they were to prevent an immediate confrontation, viewing the current unrest as a minor dispute that Silver could resolve if given the chance.
The captain proposed a strategy: to allow the men an afternoon ashore.

He explained the potential outcomes: if all the men went ashore, the cabin party could attempt to reclaim the ship; if none went, they would fortify the cabin and defend themselves; if only some went, he was confident Silver would ensure their peaceful return.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: We held a council in the cabin.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: If some go, you mark my words, sir, Silver’ll bring ’em aboard again as mild as lambs.”

events.text_segment:
We held a council in the cabin.
“Sir,” said the captain, “if I risk another order, the whole ship’ll come about our ears by the run. You see, sir, here it is. I get a rough answer, do I not? Well, if I speak back, pikes will be going in two shakes; if I don’t, Silver will see there’s something under that, and the game’s up. Now, we’ve only one man to rely on.”
“And who is that?” asked the squire.
“Silver, sir,” returned the captain; “he’s as anxious as you and I to smother things up. This is a tiff; he’d soon talk ’em out of it if he had the chance, and what I propose to do is to give him the chance. Let’s allow the men an afternoon ashore. If they all go, why we’ll fight the ship. If they none of them go, well then, we hold the cabin, and God defend the right. If some go, you mark my words, sir, Silver’ll bring ’em aboard again as mild as lambs.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
**text_segment**: We held a council in the cabin.

"Captains Smollett, gentlemen," said the captain, "I've a word to say to you. I've a right to speak now, I believe, being the only man aboard who can command a chart. This crew beats me, and I'm not going to pretend I don't fear a mutiny. I see trouble brewing. Now, Mr. Trelawney, you've been talking pretty big to some of these men today. I understand you've been hot, and they've been insolent, and—I'm speaking rough, but I mean well—you've been a bit of a fool, sir."

"Captain Smollett," began the squire, his face all crimson with anger.

"Softly, softly, sir," said the captain. "One more step in the way of insubordination, and I'll clap you in irons. Give me leave, sir. I've failed in my duty if I've not made you understand that you're in danger. As for this crew, they'll lower a boat or I'm mistaken. And I'll tell you what I propose to do—give them the chance. Let them go ashore if they like. If they all go, well and good, we'll fight the ship. If they none of them go, well then, we hold the cabin, and God defend the right. If some go, you mark my words, sir, Silver'll bring 'em aboard again as mild as lambs."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
We held a council in the cabin. The situation was dire, with the pirates now in control of much of the island. Captain Smollett laid out our predicament plainly - we were outnumbered, low on supplies, and in a precarious position. Dr. Livesey suggested we might negotiate, but the captain dismissed this notion, believing the buccaneers would show no honor in any agreement.

Jim Hawkins, though young, offered valuable intelligence about the island's geography he had gathered during his explorations. Squire Trelawney, despite his earlier indiscretion that had led to our troubles, now showed remarkable resolve, offering his marksmanship in our defense.

We took inventory of our weapons and provisions, marking a crude map of our defensive position. The stockade would be our fortress, we decided, and we would need to transport everything valuable from the ship before the tide changed.

As our council concluded, we agreed on watches and signals, knowing that our survival depended on unity and vigilance against Silver and his mutinous crew.

events.title: Executing the Plan: Shore Leave and Tenuous Alliances
detailed_summary: The captain's plan to allow the men ashore was approved.
Loaded pistols were distributed to all the dependable members of their party.
Hunter, Joyce, and Redruth were brought into their confidence regarding the situation and the plan; they reacted with less surprise and greater resolve than had been anticipated.
The captain then went on deck and addressed the crew.
He announced that due to the hot day and general fatigue, anyone who wished could take the ship's gigs for an afternoon ashore, with a gun to be fired as a recall signal half an hour before sunset.
Jim surmised that the crew, in their naivety, must have imagined they would immediately find treasure upon landing.
Their sullenness vanished instantly, and they let out a cheer that echoed from a distant hill, once again disturbing the birds around the anchorage.
The captain, displaying his astuteness, quickly withdrew from sight, leaving Silver to organize the shore party, a decision Jim considered prudent.
Jim reflected that if the captain had remained on deck, he could no longer have feigned ignorance of the true state of affairs: Silver was effectively in command of a highly rebellious crew.

He pondered the nature of the 'honest hands' aboard, concluding they were either exceptionally dull or, more likely, that all crew members were disaffected by the ringleaders' influence to varying degrees, though only a few were good men at heart who couldn't be pushed further into outright villainy.
He acknowledged the significant difference between idleness and disobedience versus actively seizing a ship and murdering innocent people.

events.text_segment:
It was so decided; loaded pistols were served out to all the sure men; Hunter, Joyce, and Redruth were taken into our confidence and received the news with less surprise and a better spirit than we had looked for, and then the captain went on deck and addressed the crew.
“My lads,” said he, “we’ve had a hot day and are all tired and out of sorts. A turn ashore’ll hurt nobody—the boats are still in the water; you can take the gigs, and as many as please may go ashore for the afternoon. I’ll fire a gun half an hour before sundown.”
I believe the silly fellows must have thought they would break their shins over treasure as soon as they were landed, for they all came out of their sulks in a moment and gave a cheer that started the echo in a faraway hill and sent the birds once more flying and squalling round the anchorage.
The captain was too bright to be in the way. He whipped out of sight in a moment, leaving Silver to arrange the party, and I fancy it was as well he did so. Had he been on deck, he could no longer so much as have pretended not to understand the situation. It was as plain as day. Silver was the captain, and a mighty rebellious crew he had of it. The honest hands—and I was soon to see it proved that there were such on board—must have been very stupid fellows. Or rather, I suppose the truth was this, that all hands were disaffected by the example of the ringleaders—only some more, some less; and a few, being good fellows in the main, could neither be led nor driven any further. It is one thing to be idle and skulk and quite another to take a ship and murder a number of innocent men.

events.title: Jim's Impulsive Escape Ashore
detailed_summary: Eventually, the shore party was formed, with six men designated to stay aboard the Hispaniola, while the remaining thirteen, Silver among them, prepared to embark.
At this point, Jim conceived the first of several impulsive ideas that would ultimately contribute significantly to saving their lives.
He reasoned that since Silver was leaving only six men on the ship, the cabin party could not successfully retake it at that moment.
Conversely, with only six adversaries remaining on board, the cabin party did not immediately require his assistance for their defense.
He instantly decided to go ashore himself.
In a swift movement, he slipped over the side of the Hispaniola and concealed himself in the fore-sheets of the nearest boat just as it was pushing off.
Most of the boat's occupants did not notice him, apart from the bow oarsman, who casually asked if it was Jim and told him to keep his head down.
However, Long John Silver, in the other boat, looked over sharply and called out, questioning if it was indeed Jim.
From that moment, Jim began to feel regret for his hasty decision.
The crews of both boats raced towards the beach.
The boat Jim was in, having a slight lead and being both lighter and better manned, quickly outpaced its companion.
As his boat's bow struck the shore among the trees, Jim seized a branch, swung himself out, and plunged into the nearest thicket, while Silver and the others were still a hundred yards behind.
He heard Silver shouting his name, "Jim, Jim!".
Jim, however, paid no attention, instead jumping, ducking, and forcing his way through the undergrowth, running straight ahead until he could run no more.

events.text_segment:
At last, however, the party was made up. Six fellows were to stay on board, and the remaining thirteen, including Silver, began to embark.
Then it was that there came into my head the first of the mad notions that contributed so much to save our lives. If six men were left by Silver, it was plain our party could not take and fight the ship; and since only six were left, it was equally plain that the cabin party had no present need of my assistance. It occurred to me at once to go ashore. In a jiffy I had slipped over the side and curled up in the fore-sheets of the nearest boat, and almost at the same moment she shoved off.
No one took notice of me, only the bow oar saying, “Is that you, Jim? Keep your head down.” But Silver, from the other boat, looked sharply over and called out to know if that were me; and from that moment I began to regret what I had done.
The crews raced for the beach, but the boat I was in, having some start and being at once the lighter and the better manned, shot far ahead of her consort, and the bow had struck among the shore-side trees and I had caught a branch and swung myself out and plunged into the nearest thicket while Silver and the rest were still a hundred yards behind.
“Jim, Jim!” I heard him shouting.
But you may suppose I paid no heed; jumping, ducking, and breaking through, I ran straight before my nose till I could run no longer.

events.title: Jim's Solitary Exploration and Initial Sense of Freedom
detailed_summary: Feeling elated after successfully evading Long John, Jim begins to observe his surroundings with keen interest.
He traverses a marshy area filled with various unfamiliar swamp vegetation before reaching an open, sandy expanse dotted with pines and peculiar, pale-leafed trees resembling oaks.
In the distance, a hill with two distinct, sunlit peaks stands out.
Jim experiences the pure joy of exploration for the first time, believing the island to be uninhabited by humans, leaving only him and the native wildlife.
He wanders among the trees, encountering unknown flowering plants and snakes, one of which hisses at him with a sound he doesn't recognize as the warning rattle of a deadly creature.
He then comes across a dense thicket of evergreen oaks, growing low like brambles with curiously twisted boughs, stretching towards a broad, reedy fen.
The marsh appears to be steaming in the heat of the sun, and the distant Spy-glass hill shimmers through the haze.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I was so pleased at having given the slip to Long John that I began to enjoy myself and look around me with some interest on the strange land that I was in.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The marsh was steaming in the strong sun, and the outline of the Spy-glass trembled through the haze.

events.text_segment:
I was so pleased at having given the slip to Long John that I began to enjoy myself and look around me with some interest on the strange land that I was in.
I had crossed a marshy tract full of willows, bulrushes, and odd, outlandish, swampy trees; and I had now come out upon the skirts of an open piece of undulating, sandy country, about a mile long, dotted with a few pines and a great number of contorted trees, not unlike the oak in growth, but pale in the foliage, like willows. On the far side of the open stood one of the hills, with two quaint, craggy peaks shining vividly in the sun.
I now felt for the first time the joy of exploration. The isle was uninhabited; my shipmates I had left behind, and nothing lived in front of me but dumb brutes and fowls. I turned hither and thither among the trees. Here and there were flowering plants, unknown to me; here and there I saw snakes, and one raised his head from a ledge of rock and hissed at me with a noise not unlike the spinning of a top. Little did I suppose that he was a deadly enemy and that the noise was the famous rattle.
Then I came to a long thicket of these oaklike trees—live, or evergreen, oaks, I heard afterwards they should be called—which grew low along the sand like brambles, the boughs curiously twisted, the foliage compact, like thatch. The thicket stretched down from the top of one of the sandy knolls, spreading and growing taller as it went, until it reached the margin of the broad, reedy fen, through which the nearest of the little rivers soaked its way into the anchorage. The marsh was steaming in the strong sun, and the outline of the Spy-glass trembled through the haze.

I was so pleased at having given the slip to Long John that I began to enjoy myself and look around me with some interest on the strange land that I was in. The marsh where I had landed was studded with willow-like trees and strange, unfamiliar plants that thrived in the boggy soil. After traversing this swampy region, I came upon a more open area, sandy and scattered with pine trees. Among them grew curious trees with pale leaves that reminded me somewhat of oak trees, though unlike any I had seen in England.

In the distance rose a hill with two sharp peaks catching the sunlight, standing clear against the blue sky. I felt a thrill of adventure such as I had never known before. Here I was, alone on an island that seemed untouched by human hands, with only the wild creatures for company. The thought filled me with a strange exhilaration rather than fear.

As I wandered among the trees, I discovered flowering plants of shapes and colors unknown to me. Snakes slithered away at my approach, and one raised its head and made a curious dry sound that I did not recognize. Had I been more knowledgeable of such creatures, I might have known it for the warning rattle of a deadly serpent.

Presently I came upon a thicket most peculiar in appearance - a growth of evergreen oaks, if such they could be called, that grew not tall and stately as oaks should, but low and twisted like brambles, their boughs contorted in fantastic shapes. This strange wood bordered a wide, reedy fen from which vapors rose in the heat of the day. Through this misty air, the Spy-glass hill seemed to shimmer and dance, as if seen through the distortion of a dream.
```

events.title: Alarmed by Approaching Voices, Jim Takes Cover
detailed_summary: A sudden commotion among the bulrushes, with wild ducks taking flight and a large flock of birds circling and screaming above the marsh, startles Jim.
He immediately infers that some of his shipmates must be approaching the fen's edge.
His suspicion is confirmed when he hears faint human voices that steadily grow louder and closer.
Gripped by intense fear, Jim quickly conceals himself beneath the branches of the nearest live-oak tree, listening intently and remaining as still as possible.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: All at once there began to go a sort of bustle among the bulrushes; a wild duck flew up with a quack, another followed, and soon over the whole surface of the marsh a great cloud of birds hung screaming and circling in the air.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: This put me in a great fear, and I crawled under cover of the nearest live-oak and squatted there, hearkening, as silent as a mouse.

events.text_segment:
All at once there began to go a sort of bustle among the bulrushes; a wild duck flew up with a quack, another followed, and soon over the whole surface of the marsh a great cloud of birds hung screaming and circling in the air. I judged at once that some of my shipmates must be drawing near along the borders of the fen. Nor was I deceived, for soon I heard the very distant and low tones of a human voice, which, as I continued to give ear, grew steadily louder and nearer.
This put me in a great fear, and I crawled under cover of the nearest live-oak and squatted there, hearkening, as silent as a mouse.

events.title: Eavesdropping on Silver and Another Crewman's Tense Exchange
detailed_summary: Jim identifies one of the voices as Long John Silver's, engaged in what sounds like an earnest, almost fierce, discussion with another man.
Initially, he cannot make out any specific words.
The conversation seems to pause, and the speakers perhaps sit down, as they draw no nearer and the agitated birds begin to calm and resettle in the swamp.
Realizing his precarious situation and feeling it his duty to gather information about the 'desperadoes' he landed with, Jim resolves to get closer.
He uses the behavior of the few remaining alarmed birds to pinpoint the speakers' location.

Moving stealthily on hands and knees, he inches towards them until he can peer through the foliage into a small, tree-bordered green dell where Long John Silver and another crew member are conversing face to face.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Another voice answered, and then the first voice, which I now recognized to be Silver’s, once more took up the story and ran on for a long while in a stream, only now and again interrupted by the other.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Crawling on all fours, I made steadily but slowly towards them, till at last, raising my head to an aperture among the leaves, I could see clear down into a little green dell beside the marsh, and closely set about with trees, where Long John Silver and another of the crew stood face to face in conversation.

events.text_segment:
Another voice answered, and then the first voice, which I now recognized to be Silver’s, once more took up the story and ran on for a long while in a stream, only now and again interrupted by the other. By the sound they must have been talking earnestly, and almost fiercely; but no distinct word came to my hearing.
At last the speakers seemed to have paused and perhaps to have sat down, for not only did they cease to draw any nearer, but the birds themselves began to grow more quiet and to settle again to their places in the swamp.
And now I began to feel that I was neglecting my business, that since I had been so foolhardy as to come ashore with these desperadoes, the least I could do was to overhear them at their councils, and that my plain and obvious duty was to draw as close as I could manage, under the favourable ambush of the crouching trees.
I could tell the direction of the speakers pretty exactly, not only by the sound of their voices but by the behaviour of the few birds that still hung in alarm above the heads of the intruders.
Crawling on all fours, I made steadily but slowly towards them, till at last, raising my head to an aperture among the leaves, I could see clear down into a little green dell beside the marsh, and closely set about with trees, where Long John Silver and another of the crew stood face to face in conversation.

events.title: Silver's Attempt to Persuade Tom and Tom's Unwavering Loyalty
detailed_summary: Silver, his hat discarded and his face shiny with heat, is seen appealing to the other man, Tom.
Silver professes to hold Tom in high regard, like 'gold dust,' and claims his current words are a warning intended to save Tom's life.
He implies that if the 'wild uns' (other mutineers) knew he was warning Tom, he himself would be in danger.
Tom, red-faced and with a hoarse, shaking voice, responds to Silver.
He acknowledges Silver's age, reputation for honesty, financial standing (unlike many sailors), and perceived bravery.
Tom expresses his profound disbelief that Silver would allow himself to be swayed by a 'mess of swabs,' i.e., the mutinous crew.
He staunchly declares that he would rather lose his own hand than betray his duty.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The sun beat full upon them.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: If I turn agin my dooty—”

events.text_segment:
The sun beat full upon them. Silver had thrown his hat beside him on the ground, and his great, smooth, blond face, all shining with heat, was lifted to the other man’s in a kind of appeal.
“Mate,” he was saying, “it’s because I thinks gold dust of you—gold dust, and you may lay to that! If I hadn’t took to you like pitch, do you think I’d have been here a-warning of you? All’s up—you can’t make nor mend; it’s to save your neck that I’m a-speaking, and if one of the wild uns knew it, where’d I be, Tom—now, tell me, where’d I be?”
“Silver,” said the other man—and I observed he was not only red in the face, but spoke as hoarse as a crow, and his voice shook too, like a taut rope—“Silver,” says he, “you’re old, and you’re honest, or has the name for it; and you’ve money too, which lots of poor sailors hasn’t; and you’re brave, or I’m mistook. And will you tell me you’ll let yourself be led away with that kind of a mess of swabs? Not you! As sure as God sees me, I’d sooner lose my hand. If I turn agin my dooty—”

events.title: A Distant Scream Interrupts, Heightening Tension
detailed_summary: Tom's resolute statement is abruptly cut off by an unexpected sound.
Jim notes the irony of finding one loyal man, Tom, just as this sound brings news of another, likely in peril.
From far off in the marsh, a cry of anger is heard, followed by another, and then a terrible, prolonged scream.
The scream echoes multiple times off the Spy-glass rocks, and the entire flock of marsh birds rises again, obscuring the sky with a sudden whir.
After the death yell fades from his mind, an unnerving silence returns, punctuated only by the rustling of resettling birds and the distant ocean surf.
Tom reacts to the scream with a startled jump, but Silver remains perfectly still, his gaze fixed on Tom with the intensity of a poised snake.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: And then all of a sudden he was interrupted by a noise.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Tom had leaped at the sound, like a horse at the spur, but Silver had not winked an eye. He stood where he was, resting lightly on his crutch, watching his companion like a snake about to spring.

events.text_segment:
And then all of a sudden he was interrupted by a noise. I had found one of the honest hands—well, here, at that same moment, came news of another. Far away out in the marsh there arose, all of a sudden, a sound like the cry of anger, then another on the back of it; and then one horrid, long-drawn scream. The rocks of the Spy-glass re-echoed it a score of times; the whole troop of marsh-birds rose again, darkening heaven, with a simultaneous whirr; and long after that death yell was still ringing in my brain, silence had re-established its empire, and only the rustle of the redescending birds and the boom of the distant surges disturbed the languor of the afternoon.
Tom had leaped at the sound, like a horse at the spur, but Silver had not winked an eye. He stood where he was, resting lightly on his crutch, watching his companion like a snake about to spring.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:

**text_segment**:

And then all of a sudden he was interrupted by a noise. The far-away sound of a cry of anger, such as a man might make who was enraged and struck all in a moment, came through the trees. We were too far away to be sure, but I thought it was the voice of the captain. Another followed, and then a scream of agony that went up to the sky and seemed to ring among the rocks of the Spy-glass.

At the sound of that terrible cry, all the birds rose once more in a cloud and filled the air with their screaming. Long after the scream itself had died away, their cries continued to echo and die among the rocks. The whole place seemed to have been startled into life at the sound; and I remember how the noise of the birds, the whirring of their wings, seemed to fill my ears.

Tom had leaped at the sound, like a horse at the spur, but Silver had not winked an eye. He stood where he was, resting lightly on his crutch, watching his companion like a snake about to spring.

"John!" said the sailor, stretching out his hand.

"Hands off!" cried Silver, leaping back a yard, as it seemed to me, with the speed and security of a trained gymnast.

events.title: Silver Reveals Alan's Demise; Tom's Defiant Condemnation
detailed_summary: Tom addresses Silver by name, extending his hand, but Silver sharply rebuffs him, telling him to keep his hands off.
Tom retorts that only a guilty conscience could make Silver afraid of him and urgently asks about the scream.
Silver, with a feigned smile but increased wariness, his eye gleaming like glass, casually suggests the scream was likely Alan's.
Upon hearing this, Tom reacts with heroic fury, declaring Alan a true seaman whose soul should rest in peace.
He then decisively renounces his long-standing association with Silver, stating their companionship is over.
Tom bravely proclaims he will die fulfilling his duty and defies Silver to kill him if he can.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “John!” said the sailor, stretching out his hand.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But I defies you.”

events.text_segment:
“John!” said the sailor, stretching out his hand.
“Hands off!” cried Silver, leaping back a yard, as it seemed to me, with the speed and security of a trained gymnast.
“Hands off, if you like, John Silver,” said the other. “It’s a black conscience that can make you feared of me. But in heaven’s name, tell me, what was that?”
“That?” returned Silver, smiling away, but warier than ever, his eye a mere pin-point in his big face, but gleaming like a crumb of glass. “That? Oh, I reckon that’ll be Alan.”
And at this point Tom flashed out like a hero.
“Alan!” he cried. “Then rest his soul for a true seaman! And as for you, John Silver, long you’ve been a mate of mine, but you’re mate of mine no more. If I die like a dog, I’ll die in my dooty. You’ve killed Alan, have you? Kill me too, if you can. But I defies you.”

events.title: The Brutal Murder of Tom by Long John Silver
detailed_summary: Following his defiant words, the courageous Tom turns his back on Silver and starts walking towards the beach.
His journey is cut short as Silver, with a cry, grabs a tree branch for balance, yanks his crutch from his armpit, and hurls the makeshift weapon through the air.
The crutch strikes Tom with tremendous force directly between his shoulders, causing him to gasp and fall.
It is implied that Tom's back might have been broken by the impact.
Before Tom has any chance to recover, Silver, moving with surprising agility for a man with one leg, is upon him.
Silver then stabs the defenseless Tom twice with his knife, up to the hilt.
From his hiding place, Jim can hear Silver panting heavily as he delivers the fatal blows.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: And with that, this brave fellow turned his back directly on the cook and set off walking for the beach.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: From my place of ambush, I could hear him pant aloud as he struck the blows.

events.text_segment:
And with that, this brave fellow turned his back directly on the cook and set off walking for the beach. But he was not destined to go far. With a cry John seized the branch of a tree, whipped the crutch out of his armpit, and sent that uncouth missile hurtling through the air. It struck poor Tom, point foremost, and with stunning violence, right between the shoulders in the middle of his back. His hands flew up, he gave a sort of gasp, and fell.
Whether he were injured much or little, none could ever tell. Like enough, to judge from the sound, his back was broken on the spot. But he had no time given him to recover. Silver, agile as a monkey even without leg or crutch, was on the top of him next moment and had twice buried his knife up to the hilt in that defenceless body. From my place of ambush, I could hear him pant aloud as he struck the blows.

events.title: Jim's Horror and Disbelief at Silver's Callousness
detailed_summary: The shock of witnessing the murder causes Jim to experience a profound sense of disorientation; his vision blurs, the world seems to spin, and he hears illusory sounds.
When he recovers his senses, he sees Silver has calmly retrieved his crutch and put on his hat.
Tom lies motionless on the ground nearby, but Silver pays him no attention.
Instead, the murderer is seen casually cleaning his blood-stained knife on a wisp of grass.
The peaceful, unchanged surroundings—the sunlit marsh and mountain—make it difficult for Jim to accept the brutal reality of the murder he has just witnessed.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I do not know what it rightly is to faint, but I do know that for the next little while the whole world swam away from before me in a whirling mist; Silver and the birds, and the tall Spy-glass hilltop, going round and round and topsy-turvy before my eyes, and all manner of bells ringing and distant voices shouting in my ear.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Everything else was unchanged, the sun still shining mercilessly on the steaming marsh and the tall pinnacle of the mountain, and I could scarce persuade myself that murder had been actually done and a human life cruelly cut short a moment since before my eyes.

events.text_segment:
I do not know what it rightly is to faint, but I do know that for the next little while the whole world swam away from before me in a whirling mist; Silver and the birds, and the tall Spy-glass hilltop, going round and round and topsy-turvy before my eyes, and all manner of bells ringing and distant voices shouting in my ear.
When I came again to myself the monster had pulled himself together, his crutch under his arm, his hat upon his head. Just before him Tom lay motionless upon the sward; but the murderer minded him not a whit, cleansing his blood-stained knife the while upon a wisp of grass. Everything else was unchanged, the sun still shining mercilessly on the steaming marsh and the tall pinnacle of the mountain, and I could scarce persuade myself that murder had been actually done and a human life cruelly cut short a moment since before my eyes.

events.title: Silver's Signal Prompts Jim's Terrified Flight
detailed_summary: John Silver takes a whistle from his pocket and blows a series of distinct, modulated blasts that carry across the air.
The sound of the whistle instantly reignites Jim's fears, as he understands it to be a signal.
He realizes more of Silver's men will be coming and that he himself might be discovered.
Recalling the deaths of Tom and Alan, Jim becomes terrified that he will be the next victim.
He immediately begins to retreat, crawling back with as much speed and stealth as he can manage towards the less dense part of the woods.
As he does so, he hears calls being exchanged between Silver and his approaching comrades, which lends speed to his escape.
Once clear of the thicket, Jim breaks into an all-out run, heedless of his direction, driven solely by the desperate need to get away from the murderers, his fear escalating into a near frenzy.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: But now John put his hand into his pocket, brought out a whistle, and blew upon it several modulated blasts that rang far across the heated air.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: and as I ran, fear grew and grew upon me until it turned into a kind of frenzy.

events.text_segment:
But now John put his hand into his pocket, brought out a whistle, and blew upon it several modulated blasts that rang far across the heated air. I could not tell, of course, the meaning of the signal, but it instantly awoke my fears. More men would be coming. I might be discovered. They had already slain two of the honest people; after Tom and Alan, might not I come next?
Instantly I began to extricate myself and crawl back again, with what speed and silence I could manage, to the more open portion of the wood. As I did so, I could hear hails coming and going between the old buccaneer and his comrades, and this sound of danger lent me wings. As soon as I was clear of the thicket, I ran as I never ran before, scarce minding the direction of my flight, so long as it led me from the murderers; and as I ran, fear grew and grew upon me until it turned into a kind of frenzy.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
**text_segment**: But now John put his hand into his pocket, brought out a whistle, and blew upon it several modulated blasts that rang far across the heated air. I had not yet recovered from my horrid fear of a minute or two before. But now this signal woke up my fears in another way. If there were seafaring men upon the island, and they too were under Silver's command, I might have little hope indeed. I was still considering this, when in the distance I heard a sound like the cry of anger, then another on the back of it; and then one horrid, long-drawn scream. The rocks of the Spy-glass re-echoed it a score of times; the whole troop of marsh-birds rose again, darkening heaven, with a simultaneous whirr; and long after that death yell was still ringing in my ears, silence had re-established its empire, and only the rustle of the redescending birds and the boom of the distant surges disturbed the languor of the afternoon.

Tom had been killed—and Alan too, perhaps; that was the end of it. And I was to be the next. My terror drove me to action. I began to run back, as fast as I could, towards the creek, and I had not gone a hundred yards when I heard voices. I crouched down among the bushes and lay perfectly still, listening. One voice I recognized as Silver's; the others were strange to me. From their talk I gathered that they were going up the island to join their comrades. This put new terrors in my heart, and I ran as I never ran before, not caring much in what direction, so long as I got away from the murderers; and as I ran, fear grew and grew upon me until it turned into a kind of frenzy.

events.title: Jim's Despair and Unwitting Arrival in a New Area
detailed_summary: Jim feels utterly lost and consumed by despair, reflecting on his perilous situation.
He believes it impossible to return to the boats or the Hispaniola, certain that the mutineers would kill him on sight, especially if they suspected he knew of their crimes.
He sees his future as holding only death, either by starvation or at the hands of the pirates.
Throughout this period of panicked thought, Jim continues to run without paying attention to his surroundings.
Unknowingly, he has drawn near the base of the small, two-peaked hill and entered a part of the island where the live-oaks are more spread out and forest-like, interspersed with tall pine trees.
He notices the air in this new location smells fresher than down by the marsh.
His desperate flight is suddenly interrupted by a new, startling event that brings him to an abrupt halt, his heart pounding with renewed alarm.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Indeed, could anyone be more entirely lost than I?
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And here a fresh alarm brought me to a standstill with a thumping heart.

events.text_segment:
Indeed, could anyone be more entirely lost than I? When the gun fired, how should I dare to go down to the boats among those fiends, still smoking from their crime? Would not the first of them who saw me wring my neck like a snipe’s? Would not my absence itself be an evidence to them of my alarm, and therefore of my fatal knowledge? It was all over, I thought. Good-bye to the Hispaniola; good-bye to the squire, the doctor, and the captain! There was nothing left for me but death by starvation or death by the hands of the mutineers.
All this while, as I say, I was still running, and without taking any notice, I had drawn near to the foot of the little hill with the two peaks and had got into a part of the island where the live-oaks grew more widely apart and seemed more like forest trees in their bearing and dimensions. Mingled with these were a few scattered pines, some fifty, some nearer seventy, feet high. The air too smelt more freshly than down beside the marsh.
And here a fresh alarm brought me to a standstill with a thumping heart.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
**text_segment**: Indeed, could anyone be more entirely lost than I? It was impossible to return to the boats. I could not get back to the stockade, for the mutineers were between; and even if I could, what good would it be? Silver and the others would be there, and I should fall from one peril into another. My own friends would not remember me; they would have given me up for dead, and gone on with their plans. If I hailed the ship, I should be shot down like a dog. To have fallen among the pirates was bad enough, but to have them know I had overheard their counsels would be certain death.

Lost, helpless, desperate, I stood there, and tears came to my eyes. As I stood there, I thought I heard a sound, and, turning quickly, saw a dark shaggy figure leap behind a tree. What it was, whether bear or man or monkey, I could not tell. I was so frightened that I ran as I had never run before, blindly, not caring where.

All the time I ran I was drawing away from the boats, and getting farther towards the two peaks of the hill they called the Spy-glass. I was now in a part of the island that I had not seen before. The trees here were far apart, and there were wide open spaces in which the sunshine fell. Here the air was clear and sweet, not like the marshes. But all this I observed with mechanical eyes, for my thoughts were whirling.

Suddenly, something happened that brought me to a standstill, and made my heart beat into my mouth.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
**text_segment**: Indeed, could anyone be more entirely lost than I? Ship lost, stockade lost, and not a soul that I could speak to. And before I could recover my spirits, the Hispaniola would be gone. Yes, there was the boat, I thought. I could try and get back to her. But the moment I saw the men on board, they would fire into me like a target. And what could I do in a boat at sea? I was as helpless as helpless could be. If they were to see me, and guess that I had overheard their counsels, my goose was cooked.

I was so utterly cast down that I forgot even to be afraid. But as I was certain to be hunted down next day, with the chart in their hands, I could not afford to waste time. What I must do was to get clear away from the neighborhood of the boats and stockade; and then I would take my chance of the weather and the island. I said good-bye to the Hispaniola, the captain, my friends, and all my adventures; and with that, I plunged into the nearest thicket, while Silver and the rest were still a hundred yards behind.

I ran as I never ran before, scarce minding the direction of my flight, so long as it led me from the murderers; and as I ran, fear grew and grew upon me, until it turned into a kind of frenzy.

Indeed, as I began to be better acquainted with the character of the island, I was in real alarm for my fate. I had seen the two peaks from the sea; they were like two teeth, and the one I was now upon was the bigger of the two, and the more inland. It was bare and steep at the top, and surrounded by loose stones, like a cairn, at the bottom. Here and there were little groves of live-oaks, not unlike those I had seen upon the lower lands, but growing more like forest trees in their height and the width of their spread, with many pines besides, some fifty, some nearer seventy, feet high. The air, too, smelt more freshly than down beside the marsh.

And here, at the bottom of a considerable valley, I was suddenly brought up. With a bound my heart was in my mouth.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_2.text:
**text_segment**: Indeed, could anyone be more entirely lost than I? Ship lost, stockade lost, nothing left me but my life, and I was doubtful if even that might stand the test of the next few minutes.

As I was thus thinking, I was sharply recalled to my immediate danger. Some of the buccaneers who had run from the boats were certainly climbing the hill towards me, and it would be only by good luck if I escaped falling into their hands. They had the chart, of course; they would hunt me down like a dog; and if they caught me, it was little I could hope from their mercy.

I felt that I must get clear away from the neighbourhood of the boats; and once I thought I had gained a fair start, I would make a bolt for life and fortune. I said good-bye to the Hispaniola, to the captain, to the squire, to the doctor, and to Joyce, Hunter, and Redruth, all of whom I thus left in the blackest danger; and I put my best foot foremost.

All this time, without knowing it, I had been running straight for the two-peaked hill, which was, indeed, the mark Silver had named for the cache. Now that I had begun to reflect, I saw how desperate a step I was taking. But desperate as it was, it was the only one possible. I was between the devil and the deep sea; I had neither ship, nor friends, nor weapons; no help could come to me from any quarter. If I was to save my life (and that was all I thought of), I must do what I was doing.

Well, as I was running, I came to the border of the wood nearest the shore. A little farther on, the ground began to rise, and I saw something bright on the face of the slope. I was sure it must be Silver and his party, and I ducked behind a bush, with my heart beating in my mouth.

The light was growing, and I could see things clear. Looking out between the stems of the trees, I could make out that the bright spot was a fire, still smouldering. Who had lit it? And why had they lit it? These were questions I could not answer.

I continued to creep forward, now flat on my face, from bush to bush, always with my eyes fixed on that fire and those dim figures that I could just make out around it. At last I was close enough to see that there were three men seated by the fire; one of them was Silver, and the others I did not know.

I was now close enough to see them clearly. The fire had burned itself out to a few embers, and the three men had finished their meal, for they were stretched out on the ground, apparently asleep. The one who was on watch had his face turned in my direction. The firelight shone full upon him; he seemed an alert, dark-eyed man, and he had a pipe in his mouth.

I turned and began to crawl away from the fire as fast as I could. As I did so, I heard the watchman hail his comrades. "Rouse up, mates!" he cried, and his voice showed me that my retreat had been observed.

I gave up crawling, therefore, and sprang to my feet, running as I never ran before, not caring in what direction, so long as I could get away from those three terrible men. As I ran, fear grew and grew upon me, until it turned into a kind of frenzy.

Indeed, as I began to be better acquainted with the character of the island, I was in real alarm for my fate. This was the hill of the two peaks; I was now in a part of the island that I had not seen before. The trees here grew more widely apart; they were more like forest trees both in their size and in the wideness of their spread; and the ground itself was less marshy and more open. The air, too, smelt more freshly than down beside the swamps.

And here, at the bottom of a considerable valley, I was suddenly brought up. With a bound my heart was in my mouth.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Based on the prompt from "Treasure Island," I can help you complete a text in the style of Robert Louis Stevenson's classic adventure novel. Here's a 190-word continuation:

Indeed, could anyone be more entirely lost than I? The island stretched before me, wild and unfamiliar, with its twisted pines and rocky outcroppings that offered no comfort to a boy far from home. The pirates' voices had faded into the distance, but their threats still rang in my ears.

I clutched the map tightly, its worn edges damp with sea spray and my own nervous sweat. Captain Flint's treasure lay somewhere on this forsaken place, but what good was gold to a lad who might never again see England's shores?

The sun beat down mercilessly as I made my way through the underbrush. Each snapping twig sounded like a pistol shot to my strained nerves. Was that Silver and his cutthroats following my trail, or merely the island's creatures going about their business?

I thought of my mother at the Admiral Benbow, how worried she must be. And honest Squire Trelawney and Dr. Livesey—did they search for me, or had they too fallen victim to the mutineers?

With nothing but my wits and courage to sustain me, I pressed on into the heart of the island.

events.title: Mysterious Encounter and Initial Fear
detailed_summary: The narrator's attention is drawn by dislodged gravel, and he spots a figure quickly hiding behind a pine tree.
He cannot discern if the figure is a bear, man, or monkey, only noting it appears dark and shaggy, which instills terror in him.
Feeling trapped between the mutineers behind and this unknown entity ahead, he momentarily views Silver as less menacing.
He decides to retreat towards the boats, cautiously looking over his shoulder.
The figure reappears and, moving with incredible speed, begins to cut off his retreat.
The narrator realizes he cannot match the figure's speed; it moves like a deer on two legs but with an unnatural, stooped posture, confirming it is a man, albeit a strange one.
He briefly thinks of cannibals and is on the verge of calling for help.
The mere fact that the creature is a man, however wild, provides some reassurance, and his fear of Silver correspondingly increases.
He pauses, considering escape routes, and the thought of his pistol flashes into his mind.
Remembering he is armed, his courage returns, and he resolutely decides to approach this man of the island.

The man, who had been observing him, steps forward as the narrator advances, then hesitates, retreats, advances again, and finally, to the narrator's utter surprise and confusion, falls to his knees, holding out clasped hands in a gesture of supplication.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: From the side of the hill, which was here steep and stony, a spout of gravel was dislodged and fell rattling and bounding through the trees.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then he hesitated, drew back, came forward again, and at last, to my wonder and confusion, threw himself on his knees and held out his clasped hands in supplication.

events.text_segment:
From the side of the hill, which was here steep and stony, a spout of gravel was dislodged and fell rattling and bounding through the trees. My eyes turned instinctively in that direction, and I saw a figure leap with great rapidity behind the trunk of a pine. What it was, whether bear or man or monkey, I could in no wise tell. It seemed dark and shaggy; more I knew not. But the terror of this new apparition brought me to a stand.
I was now, it seemed, cut off upon both sides; behind me the murderers, before me this lurking nondescript. And immediately I began to prefer the dangers that I knew to those I knew not. Silver himself appeared less terrible in contrast with this creature of the woods, and I turned on my heel, and looking sharply behind me over my shoulder, began to retrace my steps in the direction of the boats.
Instantly the figure reappeared, and making a wide circuit, began to head me off. I was tired, at any rate; but had I been as fresh as when I rose, I could see it was in vain for me to contend in speed with such an adversary. From trunk to trunk the creature flitted like a deer, running manlike on two legs, but unlike any man that I had ever seen, stooping almost double as it ran. Yet a man it was, I could no longer be in doubt about that.
I began to recall what I had heard of cannibals. I was within an ace of calling for help. But the mere fact that he was a man, however wild, had somewhat reassured me, and my fear of Silver began to revive in proportion. I stood still, therefore, and cast about for some method of escape; and as I was so thinking, the recollection of my pistol flashed into my mind. As soon as I remembered I was not defenceless, courage glowed again in my heart and I set my face resolutely for this man of the island and walked briskly towards him.
He was concealed by this time behind another tree trunk; but he must have been watching me closely, for as soon as I began to move in his direction he reappeared and took a step to meet me. Then he hesitated, drew back, came forward again, and at last, to my wonder and confusion, threw himself on his knees and held out his clasped hands in supplication.

events.title: The Marooned Man Reveals Himself as Ben Gunn
detailed_summary: The narrator halts again and asks the figure for his identity.
The man responds in a strained, rough voice, identifying himself as Ben Gunn and stating he hasn't conversed with a Christian for three years.
The narrator now sees that the man is white, like himself, with rather pleasant features despite his condition.
His exposed skin is severely sunburnt, his lips are black, and his light-colored eyes appear striking against his darkened face.

He is described as the epitome of raggedness, clothed in tatters of old ship's canvas and sea-cloth, patched together with an eclectic mix of fastenings including brass buttons, pieces of stick, and loops of tarry rope yarn.
The only sturdy item in his attire is an old brass-buckled leather belt around his waist.
The narrator exclaims at the mention of three years and inquires if Gunn was shipwrecked.
Gunn clarifies that he was marooned.
The narrator recognizes the term 'marooned' as a horrifying form of punishment common among buccaneers, where an offender is abandoned on a remote island with minimal provisions.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At that I once more stopped.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I had heard the word, and I knew it stood for a horrible kind of punishment common enough among the buccaneers, in which the offender is put ashore with a little powder and shot and left behind on some desolate and distant island.

events.text_segment:
At that I once more stopped.
“Who are you?” I asked.
“Ben Gunn,” he answered, and his voice sounded hoarse and awkward, like a rusty lock. “I’m poor Ben Gunn, I am; and I haven’t spoke with a Christian these three years.”
I could now see that he was a white man like myself and that his features were even pleasing. His skin, wherever it was exposed, was burnt by the sun; even his lips were black, and his fair eyes looked quite startling in so dark a face. Of all the beggar-men that I had seen or fancied, he was the chief for raggedness. He was clothed with tatters of old ship’s canvas and old sea-cloth, and this extraordinary patchwork was all held together by a system of the most various and incongruous fastenings, brass buttons, bits of stick, and loops of tarry gaskin. About his waist he wore an old brass-buckled leather belt, which was the one thing solid in his whole accoutrement.
“Three years!” I cried. “Were you shipwrecked?”
“Nay, mate,” said he; “marooned.”
I had heard the word, and I knew it stood for a horrible kind of punishment common enough among the buccaneers, in which the offender is put ashore with a little powder and shot and left behind on some desolate and distant island.
